1C9A452A64E04A329AA6B6CCE2F96A80.description: Develop and/or revise personal and career goals based on the work placement experience.

46921208F3974C3B89C7C4FFA10F21AA.description: Prepare a letter, note, card or other communication for the work placement employer, expressing appreciation.

AEB41E1D92A34250BB220983A4C1C1BF.description: Update personal career documentation (e.g., resume, portfolio) following the work placement.

90C46939FFF9463A969EFAE32D81B940.description: Reflect on the attainment of personal and learning goals.

1D4C8AF2936D44F3B41B74C848789F4A.description: Showcase one’s skills and abilities demonstrated during the work placement using artifacts, evidence of skill development and personal reflections on aspects of the work experience such as: hours worked; responsibilities and tasks performed; the importance of attitude towards work and taking responsibility for what needs to be done; details about the entry level wage, salary scales and earning potential; worker rights and responsibilities and the role of the union, if applicable; ownership structure (e.g., corporation, franchise, sole proprietorship, partnership); and, opportunities for advancement at the workplace and elsewhere in the industry

35583E9AE4F64E7EB75E4F87F0F83FD5.description: Relate one’s work placement experience to personal and career goals.

6DD024ED96F444B998C50C15DC63C320.description: Document knowledge and awareness of employment standards, safety, workplace ethics, rights and responsibilities, occupational health and safety, and networking observed during the work placement.

AA581BF718DB4C74AEF669D4929D2935.description: Document one’s experience using electronic and other tools (e.g., vlogs, blogs, log sheets, reflective journals) to summarize and reflect upon items such as: hours of work including breaks; responsibilities and tasks performed; interactions with the employer, staff, customers and others; company or organization’s ‘raison d’être;’ and, skills developed and demonstrated during the work placement that enhance one’s employability.

C3FAC06ADAF64F7DBDF86EFA4E5FE614.description: Apply relevant skills and abilities during the work placement experience.

DE1688D5589A401691DF50A67CD3C520.description: Participate in a work placement experience.

BEFA27F0C9E04FF4B0F1E3F84044A614.description: Reflect upon one’s performance during the interview.

5C4A9393C6524A23B4C0BC602475EFA2.description: Participate in an interview with the employer prior to beginning the work placement.

D048A296773F49E99500528789A47087.description: Develop a list of questions that could potentially be asked by the employer/work placement in an interview situation as well as answers to the questions.

9E4006323CDE4457A7E4F980D9A9DF43.description: Brainstorm a list of questions to ask the employer before beginning the work placement; these may include: What is my schedule of work hours?, Who is my supervisor?, What should I wear?, When will I be provided with safety training?, What potential hazards might I encounter in the work placement?, Where do I find fire extinguishers, first aid kits and emergency assistance?, What type of safety gear am I expected to wear? Is it provided?, What should I do if I get injured or have an accident in the workplace?, How can I contact my health and safety committee or representative?, Are there any health and safety procedures I should follow?, Who is the first aid person?, Where are safety notices posted?, What should I do in case of a fire or emergency?

E47B0C211D294D2DA63692073C038380.description: Compile an employer information package that includes documents needed for the work placement (e.g., personal career documentation such as a resume or portfolio, permission forms, logs, self- and employer evaluation forms).

F4632EFB894A48EBB3391B98071CA162.description: Develop a procedural guide for the work placement that includes items such as: transportation to and from the work placement; hours of work; guidelines for absence and tardiness; dress code; job description; and, conflict resolution

DB17AF19C9A0495BAEDC67B3F1D0D31D.description: In collaboration with all partners, develop personal and learning goals for the work placement

F87F5C94764B4FAEA68869B95AE654E9.description: Research the business/organization to become familiar with its operations

AF5B40375C1F4434AB4C5B93DF5D3382.description: Explain the roles and responsibilities of each partner (e.g., student, parent, teacher or other school staff, employer) involved in the work placement.

DDD6802C9B25460FBED39B59448CB0C0.description: Describe and reflect on the three basic rights that all workers have under Part III – Occupational Health and Safety in The Saskatchewan Employment Act, 2019: the right to know – the hazards at work and how to control them; the right to participate – in finding and controlling workplace hazards; and, the right to refuse – work that you believe is unusually dangerous

D14D1C28E3EE4104A95AF8AC11B1856F.description: Explore the benefits of contact with nature on children’s mental health.

43A06C5FF4464922AC7A8AEDAB085781.description: Investigate behaviour that communicates confidence, self-esteem, courage and optimism around children

872F33DD9C314DC989B28AFA6B9B029C.description: Demonstrate acknowledging and labeling young children’s feelings.

2C3643A6D5654B32B7ED614C16F24C5C.description: Investigate strategies to alleviate stress and anxiety in children (e.g., breathing exercises, art therapy, sensory experiences, spending time outdoors, laughter, roughhousing).

6B9E834739E14ADB84CCC862CA9DA193.description: Discuss appropriate positive ways to respond to a child’s cues

309FB6B6579146F39ACC03E864EE4336.description: Identify ways to recognize and interpret a child’s cues.

EDF6233AC35B42F494B1DCCA7F6E90F3.description: Explore the differences in infant temperaments (e.g., easy going, slow to warm up, active) and their impact later in childhood.

61379F84E9EE4444A15D3B0873F6E8D5.description: Describe the characteristics of an environment that promotes good mental health and self-esteem (e.g., safe place to express emotions, staff interactions, greetings, children feeling valued, positive relationships with the children and families).

85FE993A666C4688B678BBCA9C3F3CD1.description: Investigate how to support children’s mental health and self-esteem in early learning and child care environments.

CFC97D9DCAC1465F8EF30B50A76B5F03.description: Design, sketch or create a representation of an early childhood outdoor environment

E42292D1CF6C4B43A801E2FF7ED89B75.description: Investigate possible resources available within the community to actualize the design of an early learning outdoor environment

029FC3EF3CD24D7D8E3D4E46D48D25C9.description: Evaluate elements (e.g., landscaping, structures, equipment) of an existing outdoor early childhood environment.

382B0C9754BA4BBA95A932E9A084D01B.description: Identify opportunities and challenges of playing outdoors in all seasons.

2AE839B5D9D94B22926610D34B98E0B8.description: Investigate local settings in the community to explore the outdoors with children in multiple seasons.

925DC98770B34B5D947C1D3439B710E2.description: Identify outdoor elements that could be brought indoors (e.g., growing seeds inside, watching bugs in bug keepers, collecting pine cones for an art project).

9C167F4915714FE487AA76F2333653CF.description: Examine the benefits of gardening with children (e.g., providing sensory experiences, engaging families, developing a deeper understanding of where food comes from).

BC29BE23CF1D41F6A4D5AD580EEF3DFF.description: Identify materials that support and extend children’s learning outdoors (e.g., magnifying glasses, identification books, bug keepers, shovels, rakes).

F89DF1B5664B46E6AE05A28177017615.description: Discuss ways to ensure safety when in outdoor environments (e.g., close supervision around water, sun protection measures, cold weather clothing).

D33D47EA116D4425819E01DEB105D1BC.description: Discuss strategies to adapt early learning outdoor environments for the safety of children with diverse abilities, temperaments or interests.

51DE9D79C9774957996C0DA29413A69E.description: Explore various ways to encourage water play (e.g., going out in the rain, allowing children to play with mud, setting up materials and structures for water play, freezing water with food coloring).

DEFE1706423C47049AE0E746C6F3B9F9.description: Identify indoor materials (e.g., art materials, blocks, dress-up clothes, cars) or loose parts (e.g., recycled tubes, cans, tree branches, sea shells) that could be brought outdoors to inspire and extend creative play.

A4B45B0E3FA74738BCD3617C4C942155.description: Identify elements of an optimal outdoor early childhood learning environment, including: landscaping with various elevations (e.g., hills, slopes, ramps) and textures (e.g., grass, gravel, sand, boulders); trees and shrubs with various textures of leaves, branches and bark; plants and flowers native to Saskatchewan to attract insects and birds; equipment to support large muscle development, coordination and balance (e.g., tunnels, stairs, bridges, raised platforms, balance beams); sheltered areas for protection from the sun and the rain (e.g., canopies, sheds, tipi structures, gazebos); cozy places to gather; performance areas and outdoor musical instruments; creative water play options; and, accessibility.

5BA7639D2812405881CC9A4BCBFB8FFD.description: Investigate the benefits of outdoor play for child development.

4CB40B67EBFE4568A51683BEAC9507A4.description: Investigate the benefits of outdoor play for child development.

478C8091FDF447C190480901658A00D1.description: Analyze outdoor early learning and child care environments.

ABB93A230AC144ECB54AF7D91FC8267C.description: Design, sketch or create a representation of a floor plan of an early childhood setting

E665006DCA6E485D9D82C8A75010E001.description: Discuss strategies to adapt the environment for children with diverse abilities, temperaments or interests (e.g., quiet spaces, muted color palates, natural light, natural materials).

A5280C9FD2A94049B34BF559E9C9AB96.description: Explain how to safely adapt accessible learning environments for children with exceptionalities.

B78417506D7C4E3DB933DA34BB4B2746.description: Explore ways to make an early learning indoor environment visually appealing, comfortable, homelike and culturally relevant.

4AC51364FCC9484A8DB6C17B5AA1A12A.description: Discuss how to set up a room to encourage positive interactions and behaviours.

26BDD7F964034B2DB4AFC051BEC9F08B.description: Explore ways to ensure safety and accessibility in indoor early learning environments.

37A30326CE3A477CBBF4289196CF5C05.description: Compare indoor play spaces organized according to play schemas and centres.

761F7ABB9359400B81584C8915C96172.description: Examine the micro level (i.e., specific materials found within the space) set up for an early childhood learning environment such as accessibility and flexibility of materials, types and quantities of materials available and the cultural and linguistic relevance of materials for the children and their families.

9294239B096A4DC8AAD9711E19692645.description: Examine the macro level (i.e., overall environment) configuration of an early childhood learning environment, such as the location of furniture, accessibility, pathways and flooring and windows for natural light.

7A44C51665F645C0A4539986E4C8CE9C.description: Observe the differences between infant, toddler and preschooler indoor environments.

9E99E5106B154C0E8D08404EC8D4EC4D.description: Identify elements of an optimal indoor early childhood learning environment, including: areas with clearly defined boundaries; open areas for music and movement; small areas defined by shelving units, carpets; creative arts area for sensory inquiry and messy play; areas planned for literacy and numeracy experiences; visual displays at children’s eye level; quiet spaces for decompression; carefully placed culturally diverse materials; and, nature areas to bring outdoor exploration indoors;

B91574E4C17B4EB3B52EB3A5542A5390.description: Analyze indoor early learning and child care environments.

C74828D287C0461AA6BA1643127817EF.description: Create a visual schedule of the daily routine including transitions and time for free play.

8154459253F64AA9B4F066555F83FD3C.description: Research various cultural practices related to routines.

47CE01F5CA25465B9A643DBCAB3D006F.description: Explore the sleeping routines of infants, toddlers and preschoolers in an early learning and child care environment.

A8D31D4E1D4C42D696160356075D658C.description: Investigate how professionals in early learning and childcare environments support families with potty training routines.

F86FFCB5AB2D4BC88F828DF4B5E27738.description: Identify challenging moments of a routine (e.g., dressing, undressing, meals, nap time) and strategies to address them.

F0EE7B1BADE14BA8A4B66B9FA94304CE.description: Discuss ways to communicate routines with parents and caregivers.

2DB93984A1C94FA2B82B8CF2D0BF1674.description: Observe how early learning and child care caregivers use transition tools.

3AF638A08EE34ED1B1FAE5E868704628.description: Evaluate various types of transition tools such as visual cues, rhymes, music and gestures

BB330DB4BA60425CA3E196C66CACFD18.description: Discuss how to keep transitions and interruptions to children’s activities to a minimum

510DA81A8AF14F29862B3260E3296F65.description: Research routines that incorporate free play.

8A7182774B1E49CBA9B6DD85CD192A8D.description: Explain the benefits of having a flexible routine (e.g., transitioning to another activity at a natural point).

B765822FF2D9425EA037C1B0FCC25455.description: Identify which parts of a daily schedule are fixed (e.g., gym time, home time) and which parts of the day may be extended or shortened, depending on the children’s interests (e.g., snack time, outdoor play, unstructured play).

608B080E90944119A4E830CF55A4BD2C.description: Explain the importance of a daily schedule for children.

40CA711B95A2458AB7E080A7B2B39914.description: Create a plan for a daily routine in an early learning and child care environment.

27D66DC8BF5F4FEBA5F4EBCD67D083E7.description: Propose possible solutions for situations that cause behavioural problems (e.g., overstimulation, break in routine, noise, waiting time, frustration, stress).

594885B75661492AB12A99CD12C31C46.description: Demonstrate giving clear guidelines with positive guidance statements such as: offering choices;showing empathy; assisting with conflict resolution; giving two-part warnings; and, using I-messages;

84E3489013724AD49E5ED027556C5094.description: Investigate suggesting (e.g., placing thoughts for consideration in children’s minds that may lead to an action) and prompting (e.g., requiring an action through verbal or non-verbal communication) as ways to guide cooperation

6EF18DCC3DB04A9BA7A1BF6B70FB63BE.description: Explain the value of following through and being consistent.

7C5CBF9B178A4A93BA0AFE884ABA0B85.description: Explore time-ins and their alternatives (e.g., special time).

72F67FD5D0B445F881ED086D0CC01B33.description: Demonstrate how to give warnings (e.g., state the misbehaviour and the consequence, one time).

93FBAFC75EB340AD82A9D8ADE0EE7DD4.description: Explore how to use natural consequences and logical consequences to guide behaviour.

CEEA5E5809234EF49CDF450AF410CB82.description: Examine conflict resolution intervention strategies for young children (e.g., when two children want the same toy, when some children are excluded from a game).

1F3533A96DB54CD4823C8B8D39FE69DD.description: Investigate strategies to assist children with regulating their emotions (e.g., naming feelings, time-ins, showing empathy)

BEBE610278BF484597ACB77ECEEC3907.description: Describe redirection strategies to avoid problem situations.

5D90809BF24549C088F7173FEFE496EC.description: Demonstrate appropriate situations to offer choices.

5FC13F4FCB174D05B2C3EE5E6ADABAD9.description: Differentiate between ineffective praise (e.g., “Good job!”) and effective praise (e.g., “You put on your coat and fastened the zipper all by yourself”)

99AD556B4D0A44C2B527DE95F270B5EF.description: Discuss how to use positive reinforcements (e.g., using appropriate praise to reinforce behaviour, checking reactions that might be perceived as a reward for inappropriate behaviour).

9EB747BD3AF0480EB184369BA079FC45.description: Investigate culturally appropriate child guidance strategies.

7D89025939B14A45BC444D4E927A3701.description: Demonstrate positive guidance statements (e.g., instead of “don’t run” say: “please walk”, instead of “don’t walk while eating food” say: “we sit while we eat”).

9E36AEB6917346EA909354455C4D5B8D.description: Differentiate between direct (e.g., involves physical and verbal actions) and indirect guidance (e.g., involves outside factors that influence behaviour such as the physical environment or routine).

6C9B5ABE42E244A7BC24E6CEAAA11FBA.description: Investigate child guidance strategies adapted to developmental milestones.

97B5B52DC2374E17B78ABCE79B873524.description: Research psychological theories for guiding behaviour (e.g., Pavlov, Skinner, Watson, Piaget).

6825428BA2734DE89D41EF4A77C04D23.description: Research child guidance strategies to promote ageappropriate behaviour.

5B555CE9FC6247249EFD9C6EA43A8074.description: Plan a one-week menu for an early learning or child care environment.

EA53FB6EDD9C4EE6A12762192120DCFB.description: Identify nutritious substitutions that could be used in a meal plan for children with specific dietary requirements (e.g. Celiac, lactose intolerance, vegetarian diet).

086B63D03E7B47E886B82212A94DE884.description: Explore meal planning guides for early learning and child care environments.

A5570BD823844D4C9880D286A9D5FA22.description: Research common food allergies (e.g., nuts, dairy products).

1B3380958CE0416EB4EEC14AD70198CE.description: Investigate ways to help children with food preferences (e.g., reassuring them that it is normal to prefer certain foods, offering appropriate serving sizes, making food appealing, involving children in the meal preparation, serving foods that reflect cultural and religious backgrounds).

E4F73440F760413D9DE7574148AF6097.description: Design a plan to create supportive food environments, including: providing regular snacks; encouraging children to eat when hungry and stop when full; allowing children to be responsible for if they eat and how much, giving positive recognition for making healthy food choices; creating a calm and pleasant environment for meals and snacks; allowing enough time for meals and snacks. promoting social development and language skills during meals; and, • talking about customs and cultures related to food.

DCF6C778A7BA420BB09460F251FB4AA5.description: Discuss ways to support breastfeeding mothers in early learning and child care environments (e.g. offering private feeding areas, accepting and storing frozen breastmilk).

1808F29A42FE44F08B41CEFEA972FDBE.description: Compare the benefits and drawbacks of various infant nutrition (e.g. breastmilk, commercial formula).

291B150E0DF341FEADE7B00ED8DF2E8B.description: Describe the beneficial effects of healthy eating patterns on the growth and development of children from birth to six years of age (e.g., increased ability to concentrate, fewer common childhood illnesses, improved overall health).

1E2C38F12D944962875E52875BCCA98D.description: Explore the link between healthy eating and physical activity.

2F714D7F232F465BA7ED704D9688E76D.description: Research nutritional information in Canada’s Food Guide for children up to age six,

C054DE6808334C27BFF599C9EFB0DB92.description: Explore how nutrition contributes to children’s health in early learning and child care environments.

EDB68229CE9F47FB9FFEC327E3132A3B.description: . Explore common special health concerns (e.g., allergies, diabetes, epilepsy, asthma) present in early learning and child care environments.

8E81546123BC4BF28220CBFF65A02A44.description: Discuss how illness should be reported to parents and caregivers.

E0F1DC6D86694B6A93866D3DBD3B4A6D.description: Explain how to care for children who become ill while in early learning and child care environments.

BBD9D7B2257B443389385BA3F534B264.description: List steps for controlling the spread of airborne and foodborne illnesses (e.g., hand washing, cough etiquette, sanitizing and disinfecting).

501082C3119442EB95716D32390B0FFB.description: Explore immunizations available in Saskatchewan to protect children at various developmental stages

C65482969E954B08BBD77BF446E4ACAB.description: Investigate common communicable diseases (e.g., chicken pox, ringworm, pertussis) in early learning and child care environments.

72CF796E115B491FAE42BE56C42D95BC.description: Describe positive environmental factors (e.g., good nutrition and dietary habits, daily physical activity, regular medical and dental care, clean and safe home environment) that influence good health in children.

6BF720B98DCA4FC68FA13EF9DEDF1520.description: Examine how diseases and infections are managed in early learning and child care environments.

27B1F8061EE8493286F9340D0E64AB0F.description: Diseases and Infections in Early Learning and Child Care Environments (Optional)

F02DEA7C545A4684A2DFA65E513F2C9E.description: Research employment opportunities in the community and abroad as a nanny, au pair or early learning and child care caregiver.

9BAF67DFB23A4361909B3C5CEF631DA5.description: Discuss how to talk about hourly pay and payment methods with clients.

9A8865B658B349AB8BBB01EF76B5702C.description: Investigate ways to find work as a babysitter in the local community.

D245E8BBC49945AF90AA3F3BEFF11020.description: Discuss strategies to babysit children with exceptionalities (e.g., safety concerns, adaptations).

89ED720A9E854C50A726845759629642.description: Plan safe activities for different age groups (e.g., organizing and leading activities for infants, toddlers, preschoolers and school aged children).

DC32EF45F7E6477EBDC8FEC3967D5BCB.description: Differentiate between hourly and full day care (e.g., weekends, days when children are sick).

F871779F563943CA81C9BE94B22D2231.description: Identify different ways of communicating with parents (e.g., texting, phoning, emailing).

8D574A42249F4FBE9950F2D4F85B2F72.description: Explore expectations of families towards babysitters (e.g., punctuality, meal preparation, homework, use of personal devices, giving baths).

08BE606C65C54F35A932E8086B449F9E.description: Research organizations offering first aid and CPR courses and discuss the benefits of such a course as a babysitter.

355A93D622644568A0D3B8FB525E183B.description: Discuss how to ensure personal safety and security as a babysitter.

B51285B5AA4A4CA79849D4B3262EDF46.description: Recognize signs of child abuse and neglect and discuss a babysitter’s responsibility for reporting.

9D1FA273892546D3A246742CBAA905B2.description: Discuss the use of personal devices when babysitting.

ADEAB9B7C0DF4066B507CA6658B0D881.description: List the responsibilities of a babysitter

1D5F06AC367442F692859D2AB3A0599A.description: Investigate the roles and responsibilities of babysitters.

C33ABAEC02CF43B28D8F19CF2DCC9F32.description: Outline procedures for treating various injuries (e.g., cuts, bites, burns, sunburns, stings).

18BFE9C2F3C8461BB18FB4C130CDB764.description: Investigate the difference between the concepts of “as safe as necessary” and “as safe as possible”

5316B0EB213C4D8D9818D624575E2B57.description: Research how worldview may impact childrearing practices in terms of safety (e.g., risky play, choice of toys, child guidance).

E28EDA041B5E43E9814E87F7D0552A9D.description: Identify choking hazards (e.g., foods, toys, strangulation and suffocation hazards) and strategies to use to mitigate risk.

CCA6DF0AD2884B85BB5506EFD30AF85A.description: Recognize foods that are dangerous for infants and toddlers (e.g., raw honey, unpasteurized milk).

884A21E82D9440458405213A951146E0.description: Explain safe use of equipment including: carriers; playpens; swings; strollers; car seats ; booster seats; and, high chairs;

2B35FF9EA42846FEAB3D14C9AAC2144D.description: Research safety precautions for all developmental stages.

8C98251F2EBB4F12854116E61F3A143E.description: Investigate household consumer products that present an injury risk to children (e.g., telephones, soaps and detergents, chairs, light bulbs, dangling blind cords).

42712A77095042989C7C54F263F36882.description: Discuss ways to prevent children from falling.

1384D4F5FAFF479C8B0ABE8B3AEE6A22.description: Identify causes of early childhood deaths from injury.

FFFCB88139BC4E48AC9ABE683B719934.description: Research the 3E’s of injury prevention (i.e., education, enforcement and engineering).

E416F8118C9A406B8FF57515087DE359.description: Examine ways to prevent injuries and promote safety of children.

676B905834D94AC18C9E0B04B95BC440.description: Safety and Injury Prevention for Children A (Optional)

3B035EF3A367458D8616A348CE6E16EB.description: Explore the cultural mandate (e.g., promotion of language and culture, choice of materials, relationship with the community) of Francophone licensed early learning child care centres.

5C997269EBAE430FA384B89761A82208.description: Explore the cultural mandate (e.g., indigenous child care theory and practices, promotion of language and culture, choice of materials, relationship with the community) of First Nations, Métis and Inuit licensed early learning child care centres.

1989C1929A4140379E0C0AEA322DCB6A.description: Compare licensed early learning child care centres to licensed family child care homes and unlicensed day homes in Saskatchewan (e.g., size, subsidy options, parent fees, regulations, training, programs, age of children accepted).

8FD4B994328A45D19C197A33EA70CD19.description: Compare licensed family child care homes to unlicensed family child care homes in Saskatchewan (e.g., subsidy options, parent fees, regulations, training, programs, age of children accepted).

8C48D7ED60C144278B1A8D0B58BBA4F5.description: Investigate how family needs might differ in urban, suburban, rural and remote communities.

8CF5678ACD444F0BB6D7381D5701EF29.description: Investigate the characteristics of at least one type of early learning and childcare environment in Saskatchewan.

C4729249F2D04A2286C702193DFD6AF7.description: Identify different types of early learning and child care environments in Saskatchewan including: unlicensed family child care homes; licensed family child care homes; preschool programs; prekindergarten programs and kindergarten programs; drop-in programs; and, early learning child care centres.

2831390D79D841659795D6BB85C70386.description: Differentiate between types of early learning and child care environments.

03DB95C33E244D15B41FD9449D6CB6EC.description: Types of Early Learning and Child Care Environments (Optional)

7D1CA2A6D3D041298A5DE743B8F409D5.description: Explore family and cultural differences in infant care practices

9468D228C7BE4A30B108491777C12D90.description: Discuss the use of cloth and disposable diaper in early learning and child care environments.

5A4D3ECC6E3E4CC5AA754DB235F4F07F.description: Discuss ways to deal with a crying infant safely (e.g., give the baby to a colleague, leave the baby in a safe place for a few minutes, never shake a baby).

CEAD39D730624CA493816DDDBE8D6F9E.description: Research safe sleep practices for infants and infant sleep cycles.

05D5729D3E2D400A98A2E16D81742300.description: Recognize signs of painful gas, colic and reflux and demonstrate holds and strategies to alleviate them.

FA8205558A304159A79B41CF3F090E25.description: Describe the various types of formulas, the water to formula ratio and appropriate bottle heating methods.

4434F530A30249B2B0613C8F366A2B05.description: Investigate how early learning and child care environments must meet the nutritional needs of infants (e.g., bottle feeding, using breast milk, formula, introduction to solid foods).

2188D74601FF4B838227E5C6080EFE01.description: Research local volunteering opportunities in caregiving environments in the community.

1A208D1EBC0945E3A840F673ADE4ED27.description: Discuss how volunteering may contribute to future employment opportunities.

B52AD6F1F29A401D9FC13AC11395408F.description: Identify the characteristics of an effective volunteer (e.g., respectful, on task, punctual, enthusiastic).

9EE7C947C8BA41A28113B5F314FDA495.description: Explore how volunteers support clients or patients in health care and early learning environments

BEEEE02627D64805A46FD94E4895A7DA.description: Examine the social and emotional benefits of volunteering in caregiving environments for everyone involved.

4410E468B1F4412CB0EA39435D067E64.description: Identify reasons to volunteer (e.g., to learn more about a career, to contribute to the community, to help others).

26351A174E45408BB01C365931298DDF.description: Outcomes Indicators Examine the role of volunteers in caregiving environments in the community.

69148632CBB74BC19F4A991673D78D93.description: Investigate ways nature is used to promote wellness in caregiving environments.

1DF09423A9D24A12A58148A90E78FC4D.description: Evaluate personal mood and stress after spending time in nature.

03999CD29B264E99AADE454DBC7FE991.description: Demonstrate how time spent in nature can impact personal connection to community.

6A3E976A8DDA4AA181E858DC64C71BAC.description: Examine how nature encourages pro-social behaviours.

80D0DC5C119842C1B129C17A28855702.description: Explore the cognitive benefits of interacting with nature.

6AC18B24CFA7444DA0CA2786574AD7F5.description: Explain the link between lack of exposure to nature and depression.

F0E4427B55F9454899E325CFC8536536.description: Investigate the impact of nature on stress and mood.

5A05BE42D0804E728CE689DF85FF7DD0.description: Evaluate how interaction with nature affects wellness in individuals.

FBB0227F05654B5C9AECD91AE3C472DF.description: Describe stages of human growth for each age group, including: early childhood; middle childhood; late childhood; adolescence; young adulthood; middle adulthood; and, late adulthood.

0D0E19A05BD548CF89E75AB12B2B1A61.description: Observe differences in development milestones between infants, toddlers preschoolers or school aged children.

06EA727D6B594315A0B668A6192F2462.description: Investigate a variety of theories related to developmental stages of human growth and development (e.g. Piaget, Erickson).

9D30FBDF17D947E69561683E4FB387A8.description: Examine the physical, social-emotional, intellectual, spiritual and intellectual developmental milestones of: infants; toddlers, preschoolers; and, school-aged children.

135D6B45638143A5AA86C7CB6757F935.description: Identify the dimensions of development (e.g. physical, socio-emotional, spiritual and intellectual).

249A6C7AB98A4AD99EB7C1B1CB7B0058.description: Identify developmental milestones and the stages of human growth.

C8E3F12781E64744B6BF541B5A76F51A.description: Developmental Milestones and Stages of Human Growth (Core)

68ED12B38BE74BA4A71F1298979E876F.description: Discuss the uses of traditional medicines and healing practices with an Elder or Knowledge Keeper.

284F46B0E5494DD9A0F6C69FF6F4A89C.description: Research Canada’s First Nations, Inuit and Métis food guide.

43E750ED1C4345269C0FB185762F5681.description: Research Métis, First Nations or Inuit care facilities in Saskatchewan (e.g., All Nations Healing Hospital, Round Prairie Elders’ Lodge, Sturgeon Lake First Nation Health Centre) and their approach to holistic care.

A946F029A682409BBC13D45564FA65E6.description: Investigate the structure of First Nations and Métis families and their role in supporting health and well-being (e.g., extended family members providing critical care).

CC58284ADE1B457DBBC6018F5F2ABC0D.description: Explore the connection between a healthy environment and individual and community health.

E69108E9BE12455CB1DAAE264E5005F0.description: Investigate ways traditional Indigenous beliefs, rituals and ceremonies can be incorporated into western health care systems (e.g., smudging, traditional medicines)

A4438C0DAFA84C5D9925C561158D655C.description: Explore how Indigenous medicinal knowledge has influenced Western medicinal practices.

573277A526EB4A8FB3FF0609186945B2.description: Research matotisân, or the Sweat Lodge, as a traditional Indigenous method of healing.

AE349FD9C90D433E9511E5AD5E90E83B.description: Compare western conceptions of health (e.g., absence of or pathology) to indigenous conceptions of health (e.g., when relationships with all things, including the land, are in balance and harmony).

FC8A9D3013D4451E900243C26B64B430.description: Engage with a local First Nations or Métis Elder to talk about traditional life stages and holistic wellness.

20376D97D2EC4AB18AB01A96FAB7857C.description: Describe the importance of achieving balance between the physical, emotional, mental and spiritual dimensions of being when providing care to others.

D6EFB460E6184804BE1D6F60EAB598FE.description: Investigate circle teachings in relation to life cycles and holistic health.

A354CE49A757454FAE3793254EFA3177.description: Explore the concept of wâhkotowin (i.e., we are all related, not only to each other, but to the Earth and all things).

331D7F5F515D4EBA811B1E59ED4C06A4.description: Examine the concept of miyo pimâtisiwin (i.e., engaging with life in a manner that is full and includes learning, growing and healing or living the good life).

336B26574B944569B6DB0ADC404D2E77.description: Explore the worldviews of health and well-being of Métis, First Nations and Inuit people in Canada.

2EF99AAAF6F542E8929829B44812EB44.description: Indigenous Worldviews of Health and Well-Being (Core)

57A66D6424884DB3AD4769174D1CE69D.description: Identify laws protocols (e.g., Highly Efficient Privacy Preserving Authentication) that regulate privacy and confidentiality in caregiving  environment.

A42E3F9485BA4F6AADA270CE5A27F08C.description: Examine strategies used to protect or respect privacy and confidentiality in caregiving environments.

F3A5E2053984433EAE489C4D4EE8449C.description: Identify situations or types of communication which may compromise the privacy and confidentiality of a care recipient.

A3C88B24D34B45A59564CFDAAB953A0B.description: Describe the role and significance of various forms used in caregiving environments such as medical release forms, parental permission forms, incident reports and consent to release information forms.

CCA637CC86254D3E89B73785D457AC0D.description: Identify situations in which sharing information is necessary.

6CFAC9F720C643B7BC51CB1CA7AA7A9E.description: Describe the importance of maintaining confidentiality.

CD37C7640702496197A572EAE50040C9.description: Describe ways to respect the privacy and confidentiality of care recipients.

55590C03F6D34694A11EEB14B25126E6.description: Demonstrate effective written email communication skills.

3935F167CFD448C4A27075B69168CB45.description: Practise using effective communication techniques for telephone conversations and text messages.

B9E4AC8406F546E49AE92E066E0AACAA.description: List common defense mechanisms (e.g., denial, displacement, passiveaggressiveness, projection, rationalization, suppression) and explain how they interfere with effective communication.

5671B3EAC4094BF0A75A6E754971A5A3.description: Explain how messages can be misinterpreted when conveyed electronically.

33CF8C9F63A84ACB8A92A79839C5A729.description: Explain the barriers to effective communication (e.g., vision problems, loud noises, lack of privacy, distractions).

69D559F23A2C484C948F29DABFF808DA.description: Explore effective communication methods (e.g., paraphrasing, empathetic listening, asking closed questions, asking open-ended questions, clarifying).

0043B64754C84EBEBFAA888C3A1BA414.description: Identify non-judgmental ways to communicate with various cultures.

5FB1B4CA26694795B5FAD64FB5AFA16F.description: Describe how a message can be understood and misunderstood.

FE273BCD669E45F3A535DB7462FE4A8F.description: Identify non-verbal communication techniques that vary among cultures.

8C3F2CC8C5994385A4C9A48FB0A7A747.description: Describe verbal and non-verbal communication (e.g., body language, touch, silence).

217A2B6F0808462E87F41D2B8A5AA8B4.description: Define professional communication and describe how it differs from other types of communication (e.g., social media posts, cell phone use).

BA49CFF2E97A4F1A80D995FB724565BC.description: Compare assertive, aggressive and passive communication styles.
